Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story:
I stood behind the register, my hands moving automatically as I scanned items and smiled at the long line of customers. The holiday rush was in full swing, and the woman in front of me was growing more agitated with every beep, her voice rising as she complained about a coupon that wouldn’t scan. I could feel the eyes of the people behind her, impatient and tired. I forced myself to stay calm, to keep my voice friendly and my smile steady, just as my manager expected.

But in the back of my mind, I kept thinking about the email I needed to send my mentor. I had a question about a term in the project brief—nothing urgent, but I knew I was supposed to communicate any confusion right away. My mentor always emphasized openness, and I didn’t want to disappoint her. Yet, with the chaos around me, I couldn’t find a moment to type out even a quick message. The pressure to be the perfect mentee tugged at me, clashing with the demand to be the ever-patient cashier. My chest tightened as I wondered which expectation I should meet first.
